trustfund:
TF025763-PHRD-AFRICA REGIONAL TRADE FACILITATION,TF040119-KENYA: DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL
            OPERATIONS (MANUAL),TF040127-ZAMBIA: DRAFT ENVIRONMENT
            OPERATIONS MANUAL,TF040641-AFRICA (TANZANIA): REGIONAL
            TRADE SEMINAR,TF093331-REGIONAL TRADE FACILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional Trade
            Facilitation Project for Africa were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: African trade
            insurance (ATI) agency plays a public sector role as a
            multilateral agency owned by multiple states, which provides
            legitimacy, allows preferred creditor status, and
            facilitates healthy peer pressure among member states to
            honor financial commitments. Imbedding self-correction and
            self-supervision mechanisms in client agencies minimizes the
            need for the Bank to play the role of a de facto regulator,
            for which it does not necessarily have sufficient resources,
            expertise, or enforcement mandate. The presence of a
            significant number of independent directors competitively
            selected for their specialized expertise in accordance with
            an agreed competence matrix may also play a critical role as
            ATI progresses towards self-supervision. More attention
            should have been given by the Bank to understanding the
            specific demand in Africa in terms of market needs, product
            mix, targeted clients, and transaction origination channels.
            Operational manuals, technical assistance, and training,
            while all necessary, are not sufficient mechanisms to ensure
            that a public sector entity like ATI will be able to keep
            pace with its internationally competitive peers and without
            taking excessive risks. Political and commercial risk
            insurance continues to be a key instrument needed to support
            private trade and investment flows in Africa.
